definition: a pause or gap in a sequence or activity
example: The band went on hiatus for three years before reuniting.

definition: a system or organization in which people or groups are ranked above or below others
example: The corporate hierarchy had seven levels from entry-level employees to CEO.

definition: excessively theatrical or dramatic
example: Her histrionic reaction to the minor problem seemed out of proportion.

definition: special honor or respect shown publicly
example: The film pays homage to classic westerns of the 1960s.

definition: of the same kind; consisting of similar parts
example: The neighborhood is becoming less homogeneous as different cultures move in.

definition: excessive pride or self-confidence
example: His hubris led him to believe he could never fail.

definition: exaggerated statements not meant to be taken literally
example: The claim that he "died of embarrassment" was mere hyperbole.

definition: a person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions
example: She was an iconoclast who challenged traditional scientific thinking.

definition: a peculiar behavioral characteristic of an individual
example: One of his idiosyncrasies was always aligning his pencils perfectly on his desk.

definition: extremely happy
example: peaceful

definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
example: The team suffered an ignominious defeat in the championship game.

definition: based on or producing illusion; deceptive
example: The apparent economic recovery proved illusory as unemployment continued to rise.

definition: about to happen
example: An announcement about the merger is imminent.

definition: unchangeable over time or unable to be changed
example: The laws of physics are immutable.

definition: treating all rivals or disputants equally
example: The judge remained impartial throughout the controversial trial.

definition: not showing or feeling emotion
example: The poker player maintained an impassive expression despite having a winning hand.

definition: not showing proper respect; rude
example: The child asked impertinent questions about the visitor's age.

definition: unable to be affected by
example: She seemed impervious to criticism.

definition: acting or done quickly and without thought or care
example: He made an impetuous decision to quit his job without having another one lined up.

definition: unable to be appeased or placated
example: She was implacable in her opposition to the proposed changes.

definition: implied though not directly expressed
example: There was an implicit agreement among the friends to avoid discussing politics.

definition: a spoken curse
example: He muttered imprecations under his breath as he tried to fix the broken pipe.

definition: failure to observe standards of honesty or modesty
example: The scandal involved financial impropriety by several executives.

definition: not having or showing foresight; spendthrift or thoughtless
example: His improvident spending left him with no savings for retirement.

definition: not showing care for the consequences of an action
example: It would be imprudent to invest all your money in a single stock.

definition: not showing due respect
example: The impudent child talked back to his teacher.

definition: dispute the truth or validity of a statement
example: The lawyer tried to impugn the witness's testimony by pointing out inconsistencies.

definition: attribute something to someone
example: The media imputed corrupt motives to the politician's actions.

definition: not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning
example: She made an inadvertent error in her calculations.

definition: lacking sense or meaning; silly
example: The movie was full of inane dialogue that added nothing to the plot.

definition: continuing without pause or interruption
example: The incessant barking of the dog kept them awake all night.

definition: just begun and so not fully formed or developed
example: The revolution was still in an inchoate stage.

definition: having or showing the ability to identify the core of an issue
example: Her incisive analysis identified the key factors behind the company's failure.

definition: a feeling that makes a person want to do something
example: She had no inclination to pursue a career in medicine.

definition: expressed in an incomprehensible or confusing way
example: His explanation was so incoherent that no one understood what he meant.

definition: not in harmony or keeping with surroundings or other aspects
example: The modern skyscraper looked incongruous among the historic buildings.

definition: not able to be corrected or reformed
example: He was an incorrigible optimist who always saw the best in every situation.

definition: unwilling or unable to believe something
example: She was incredulous when he told her he had won the lottery.

definition: necessary for someone as a duty or responsibility
example: It is incumbent upon the president to promote unity.

definition: having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned
example: She was indifferent to the praise she received for her work.

definition: originating or occurring naturally in a particular place
example: Kangaroos are indigenous to Australia.

definition: poor; needy
example: The charity provides food for indigent families in the community.

definition: feeling or showing anger because of something unjust
example: She was indignant about being overlooked for promotion.

definition: wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
example: He spent an indolent summer lounging by the pool.

definition: impossible to subdue or defeat
example: She showed indomitable courage in the face of adversity.

definition: impossible to doubt; unquestionable
example: The evidence of his guilt was indubitable.

definition: too great or extreme to be expressed in words
example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

definition: not able to be avoided or escaped
example: Death is an ineluctable fact of life.

definition: having or showing no skill
example: His inept handling of the crisis made the situation worse.

definition: a tendency to do nothing or to remain unchanged
example: Once he retired
sent: he found it hard to overcome the inertia that kept him on the couch.

definition: certain to happen; unavoidable
example: With dark clouds gathering

definition: impossible to stop or prevent
example: The inexorable advance of technology is changing every aspect of our lives.

definition: incapable of making mistakes or being wrong
example: Even the most expert doctors are not infallible.

definition: well known for some bad quality or deed
example: The area was infamous for its high crime rate.

definition: unfortunate; inappropriate
example: His infelicitous remark caused an awkward silence at the dinner table.

definition: extremely small
example: The chance of winning the lottery is infinitesimal.

definition: physical or mental weakness
example: Age brings various infirmities.

definition: a change in the pitch or tone of a person's voice
example: I could tell from the inflection in her voice that she was upset.

definition: innocent and unsuspecting
example: His ingenuous trust in others sometimes led to disappointment.

definition: bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or pleasing them
example: He tried to ingratiate himself with his new boss by complimenting her management style.

definition: tending to obstruct or harm
example: Excessive bureaucracy is inimical to innovation.

definition: gross injustice or wickedness
example: The dictator's rule was marked by iniquity and oppression.

definition: an authoritative warning or order
example: The court issued an injunction preventing the company from continuing its harmful practices.

definition: inborn; natural
example: She has an innate talent for music.

definition: not harmful or offensive
example: His comments seemed innocuous but caused unexpected offense.

definition: introducing new ideas or methods
example: The company is known for its innovative approach to problem-solving.

definition: unusually or disproportionately large
example: The project required an inordinate amount of time to complete.

definition: impossible to understand or interpret
example: His inscrutable expression gave no hint of his thoughts.

definition: proceeding in a gradual
example: subtle way with harmful effects
sent: The insidious effects of the pollution weren't noticed until years later.

definition: suggest or hint in an indirect and unpleasant way
example: She insinuated that I had not been doing my fair share of the work.

definition: lacking flavor or interest
example: The critic described the movie as an insipid attempt at comedy.

definition: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect
example: The customer was insolent to the waitstaff when his meal was delayed.

definition: showing a casual lack of concern
example: He displayed an insouciant attitude toward his approaching deadlines.

definition: unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence
example: The company's most valuable assets were intangible - its reputation and brand recognition.

definition: necessary to make a whole complete
example: Trust is an integral part of any successful relationship.

definition: able to be understood
example: The poor connection made his words barely intelligible over the phone.

definition: lacking in self-control
example: His intemperate remarks during the debate damaged his reputation.

definition: a person who takes part in a dialogue or conversation
example: The journalist proved to be a skilled interlocutor during the interview.

definition: endless or seemingly endless
example: The meeting felt interminable as it dragged into its fourth hour.

definition: destructive to both sides in a conflict
example: The company was damaged by internecine struggles between departments.

definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree
example: The intransigent position of both parties made negotiation impossible.

definition: fearless; adventurous
example: The intrepid explorer ventured into unknown territory.

definition: belonging naturally; essential
example: The intrinsic value of gold makes it a good investment during economic uncertainty.

definition: examining one's own thoughts and feelings
example: She became more introspective after her near-death experience.

definition: overwhelm with things or people to be dealt with
example: After the announcement

definition: accustom someone to something unpleasant
example: Years of working in emergency services had inured him to the sight of blood.

definition: insulting or abusive language
example: The debate degenerated into invective and personal attacks.

definition: having a particular habit or interest that is long-established
example: He's an inveterate gambler who can't resist a bet.

definition: likely to arouse resentment
example: She found herself in the invidious position of having to choose between her friends.

definition: give strength or energy to
example: The brisk walk in the cold air invigorated her.

definition: impossible to defeat or overcome
example: The team seemed invincible as they won their tenth consecutive game.

definition: never to be broken or dishonored
example: Freedom of speech is considered an inviolable right in democracies.

definition: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered
example: The irascible old man yelled at children who came near his property.

definition: irritating or annoying
example: She found her daily commute increasingly irksome.

definition: impossible to repair or make good
example: The accident caused irreparable damage to the antique vase.

definition: not able to be changed or reversed
example: Once submitted

definition: traveling from place to place
example: The itinerant worker moved wherever there were seasonal jobs available.

definition: having or showing prejudice
example: He takes a jaundiced view of any new government initiatives.

definition: naive
example: simplistic

definition: put at risk
example: The scandal jeopardized his chance of winning the election.

definition: throw or drop something from an aircraft or ship
example: They had to jettison some fuel before the emergency landing.

definition: extreme patriotism
example: especially in the form of aggressive foreign policy
sent: The newspaper was criticized for promoting jingoism during the conflict.

definition: fond of or characterized by joking; humorous
example: His jocular manner made him popular at parties.

definition: cheerful and friendly
example: The jovial host made everyone feel welcome at the party.

definition: showing good judgment
example: The manager made a judicious decision to delay the project.

definition: a huge
example: powerful

definition: a particular point in time
example: At this critical juncture
sent: we need to decide whether to continue the project.

definition: the theory or philosophy of law
example: She studied jurisprudence at Oxford University.

definition: place or deal with close together for contrasting effect
example: The documentary juxtaposes the wealth of the city with the poverty of the surrounding areas.

definition: a constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements
example: The festival was a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds.

definition: extremely difficult or complex
example: The negotiators faced a knotty problem that had no easy solution.

definition: tearful or given to weeping
example: The movie's lachrymose ending left many in the audience crying.

definition: lacking in vitality
example: force

definition: using very few words
example: His laconic reply of "maybe" left me uncertain of his intentions.

definition: a person who makes slow progress and falls behind others
example: The company was a laggard in adopting new technologies.

definition: criticize harshly
example: The critic lambasted the film for its poor acting and predictable plot.

definition: publicly criticize by using ridicule or satire
example: The sketch show lampoons political figures from all parties.

definition: lacking in vigor or vitality; slow and relaxed
example: She spent a languid afternoon reading in the hammock.

definition: lose or lack vitality; grow weak
example: The project languished after losing its main source of funding.

definition: generosity in bestowing money or gifts
example: The charity event benefited from the largesse of several wealthy donors.

definition: feeling or revealing an overt sexual interest or desire
example: He gave her a lascivious look that made her uncomfortable.

definition: existing but not yet developed or manifest
example: She had a latent talent for music that wasn't discovered until adulthood.

definition: deserving praise and commendation
example: His laudable efforts to help the community were recognized with an award.

definition: sumptuously rich
example: elaborate

definition: lack of strictness
example: severity

definition: having or showing excessive sexual desire
example: She quit her job because of her boss's lecherous behavior.

definition: conforming to the law or to rules
example: The police questioned whether his business activities were legitimate.

definition: affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic
example: The hot weather made everyone feel lethargic and unwilling to work.

definition: a lack of energy and enthusiasm
example: After lunch
sent: a lethargy seemed to settle over the office.

definition: humor or frivolity
example: especially when inappropriate
sent: The judge scolded the attorney for his levity during the serious proceedings.

definition: a person who freely indulges in sensual pleasures
example: In his youth
sent: he had been known as a libertine

definition: promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters
example: The novel was considered too licentious to be included in the school library.

definition: clear and transparent
example: Her limpid explanation made the complex subject easy to understand.

definition: treat as an object of great interest or importance
example: The returning astronauts were lionized by the media.

definition: tending to talk a great deal; garrulous
example: My loquacious seatmate on the plane told me his life story in great detail.

definition: expressed clearly; easy to understand
example: Her lucid explanation helped me understand the complex concept.

definition: so foolish or unreasonable as to be amusing
example: His claim to have read 100 books in a week was ludicrous.

definition: looking or sounding sad and dismal
example: He gave a lugubrious sigh as he contemplated the work ahead.

definition: giving off light; bright or shining
example: The luminous moon lit up the night sky.

definition: very vivid in color
example: especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or jarring effect
sent: The tabloid published lurid details of the celebrity scandal.

definition: having luster; shining
example: Her lustrous hair gleamed in the sunlight.

definition: rich and profuse in growth
example: The valley was covered with luxuriant vegetation.

definition: disturbing because concerned with or causing a fear of death
example: The haunted house was decorated with macabre images of skeletons and ghosts.

definition: generous or forgiving
example: especially toward a rival or less powerful person
sent: The champion was magnanimous in victory

definition: a wealthy and influential businessperson
example: The media magnate owned newspapers in several countries.

definition: having or showing great authority
example: The professor delivered a magisterial lecture on ancient Rome.

definition: using high-flown or bombastic language
example: His magniloquent speech impressed some but struck others as pompous.

definition: ineffective or bungling; clumsy
example: His maladroit handling of the situation only made things worse.

definition: a general feeling of discomfort or unease
example: The economic downturn created a malaise that affected consumer confidence.

definition: the mistaken use of a word in place of a similar-sounding one
example: Her malapropism
column5:
caused much amusement.,False
malcontent,a person who is dissatisfied and rebellious,The organization was challenged by a group of malcontents who opposed the new policies.,True
malediction,a curse,The defeated wizard uttered a malediction against his conqueror.,True
malefactor,a person who commits a crime or does wrong,The police were searching for the malefactor who had vandalized the park.,True
malevolent,having or showing a wish to do evil to others,The villain in the story was a malevolent sorcerer bent on revenge.,True
malfeasance,wrongdoing, especially by a public official,The mayor was investigated for malfeasance after allegations of corruption.
malign,evil in nature or effect,The drug had malign side effects that weren't discovered until years later.,True
malleable,easily influenced; pliable,Young minds are malleable and open to new ideas.,True
malodorous,smelling very unpleasant,The malodorous garbage had to be removed immediately.,True
mandate,an official order or commission to do something,The election victory gave the party a mandate to implement its policies.,True
manifest,clear or obvious to the eye or mind,The effects of the drought were manifest in the withered crops.,True
manifold,many and various,The problem has manifold causes that need to be addressed separately.,True
manipulate,control or influence cleverly or unscrupulously,The politician tried to manipulate public opinion through misleading statements.,True
marginalize,treat a person or group as insignificant or peripheral,The new policy would marginalize rural communities.,True
martial,relating to fighting or war,The country has a long martial tradition.,True
martinet,a strict disciplinarian,The new teacher was a martinet who tolerated no talking in class.,True
maudlin,self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental,After a few drinks, he became maudlin and started reminiscing about his childhood.
maunder,talk in a rambling manner,The elderly patient would maunder about events from decades ago.,True
maverick,an unorthodox or independent-minded person,He was a maverick in the industry, always trying unconventional approaches.
mawkish,sentimental in an exaggerated or false way,The film's mawkish ending was too sweet to be believable.,True
maxim,a short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct,The coach often repeated the maxim
meander,to wander aimlessly,The river meanders through the valley before reaching the sea.,True
mediate,intervene in a dispute to bring about an agreement,The diplomat tried to mediate between the warring factions.,True
mediocre,of only moderate quality; not very good,Despite good reviews, I found the movie mediocre at best.
meditation,the practice of focusing one's mind for a period of time,She found that daily meditation reduced her stress levels.,True
melancholy,a feeling of pensive sadness,The rainy weather added to her sense of melancholy.,True
mellifluous,sweet or musical; pleasant to hear,She had a mellifluous voice that was perfect for radio.,True
mendacious,not telling the truth; lying,His mendacious account of the events was soon exposed.,True
mercenary,primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics,His mercenary attitude made him unpopular with his colleagues.,True
mercurial,subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind,Her mercurial temperament made her difficult to work with.,True
meretricious,attractive in a showy or false way,The restaurant's meretricious decor couldn't compensate for its mediocre food.,True
mesmerize,capture the complete attention of someone,The dancer's performance mesmerized the audience.,True
metamorphosis,a complete change of form or character,The caterpillar undergoes a metamorphosis to become a butterfly.,True
meticulous,showing great attention to detail,She was meticulous in checking every calculation in the report.,True
milieu,a person's social environment,He thrived in the competitive milieu of Wall Street.,True
minatory,expressing or conveying a threat,The principal's minatory glare silenced the noisy classroom.,True
mindful,conscious or aware of something,She's always mindful of the impact her words can have on others.,True
minuscule,extremely small,The difference between the two products is minuscule.,True
minute,extremely small,There was a minute amount of poison, not enough to cause harm.
minutiae,the small, precise, or trivial details of something
mirage,an optical illusion caused by atmospheric conditions,The travelers saw a mirage of water in the desert.,True
mirth,amusement, especially as expressed in laughter,The comedian's jokes provoked much mirth in the audience.
misanthrope,a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society,The misanthrope lived alone in a remote cabin, avoiding all contact with people.
misconstrue,interpret wrongly,She misconstrued his silence as agreement rather than confusion.,True
miscreant,a person who behaves badly or in a way that breaks the law,The police were searching for the miscreant who had vandalized the park.,True
miser,a person who hoards wealth and spends as little as possible,Despite his millions, he lived like a miser
misogynist,a person who dislikes or is prejudiced against women,He was revealed to be a misogynist after his discriminatory hiring practices were exposed.,True
mitigate,make less severe or serious,The new measures helped mitigate the effects of the drought.,True
mnemonic,a device such as a pattern of letters that aids memory,The mnemonic Every Good Boy Deserves Fudge" helps remember musical notes.

definition: a small quantity of a particular thing
example: He showed a modicum of interest in the proposal.

definition: a small quantity of a particular thing
example: Even a modicum of exercise can improve your health.

definition: the act of changing between different states
example: The singer's voice modulation was impressive
sent: shifting easily between high and low notes.

definition: appease the anger or anxiety of someone
example: He tried to mollify the customer by offering a discount.

definition: of great importance or significance
example: They awaited the momentous decision of the Supreme Court.

definition: relating to monks or life in a monastery
example: He preferred a monastic lifestyle of simplicity and quiet.

definition: lack of variety and interest; tedious repetition
example: The monotony of the long journey made it difficult to stay awake.

definition: subject to debate or uncertainty
example: Whether this approach is better becomes a moot point if we can't afford it.

definition: at the point of death; in terminal decline
example: The moribund company was unlikely to survive another year.

definition: sullen and ill-tempered
example: He became morose after losing his job and rarely smiled.

definition: a reason for doing something
example: The police tried to establish a motive for the crime.

definition: many and of various types
example: The report outlined the multifarious causes of the economic collapse.

definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
example: She was tired of her mundane job and wanted a new challenge.

definition: characterized by great generosity
example: The munificent donation allowed the hospital to build a new wing.

definition: a countless or extremely great number
example: The night sky was filled with a myriad of stars.

definition: the lowest point
example: The company's stock reached its nadir during the financial crisis.

definition: just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential
example: The nascent technology showed promise but needed further development.

definition: wicked or criminal
example: The detective uncovered a nefarious plot to steal the crown jewels.

definition: failing to take proper care
example: The driver was found negligent in causing the accident.

definition: a newly coined word or expression
example: Social media has introduced many neologisms into everyday language.

definition: a person who is new to a subject or activity
example: As a neophyte in the financial world
sent: she had a lot to learn.

definition: the practice of favoring relatives in employment
example: His promotion was viewed as nepotism since his uncle was the CEO.

definition: irritate or annoy
example: His criticism nettled her more than she wanted to admit.

definition: a connection or series of connections
example: The investigation revealed a nexus between the company and organized crime.

definition: take small bites
example: The children nibbled on their cookies to make them last longer.

definition: appearing casually calm and relaxed
example: He was nonchalant about the upcoming exam despite its importance.

definition: so surprised and confused that one is unsure how to react
example: She was nonplussed by his unexpected marriage proposal.

definition: a medicine prepared by an unqualified person
example: The traveling salesman sold nostrums that he claimed could cure any ailment.

definition: famous for some bad quality or deed
example: The area was notorious for its high crime rate.

definition: a person new to and inexperienced in a job or situation
example: As a novice driver
sent: she was nervous on the highway.

definition: harmful or toxic to living things
example: The factory released noxious fumes into the air.

definition: of no value or importance
example: Their objections proved nugatory as the project went ahead anyway.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
example: He remained obdurate in his opposition to the new policy.

definition: render obscure or unclear
example: The politician tried to obfuscate the issue with complicated language.

definition: not aware of or concerned about what is happening
example: She was oblivious to the chaos around her as she read her book.

definition: strong public condemnation
example: The disgraced politician faced obloquy after the scandal.

definition: extremely unpleasant
example: His obnoxious behavior at the party offended many guests.

definition: not clearly expressed or easily understood
example: The professor's explanation was so obscure that few students understood it.

definition: obedient or attentive to an excessive degree
example: The obsequious waiter hovered around the table
sent: constantly asking if everything was satisfactory.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action
example: She was obstinate in her refusal to apologize.

definition: noisy and difficult to control
example: The obstreperous children made it impossible to hear the movie.

definition: slow to understand
example: He was being deliberately obtuse about the simple concept.

definition: remove a need or difficulty
example: The new system will obviate the need for manual data entry.

definition: extremely unpleasant; repulsive
example: The dictator's odious policies led to widespread human rights abuses.

definition: intrusively enthusiastic in offering help or advice
example: The officious clerk kept suggesting products I didn't want.

definition: a small group of people having control of a country or organization
example: The country had become an oligarchy controlled by a few wealthy families.

definition: giving the worrying impression that something bad is going to happen
example: The dark clouds were ominous

definition: having unlimited power; able to do anything
example: In many religions

definition: knowing everything
example: The novelist created an omniscient narrator who could see into all characters' thoughts.

definition: involving a great deal of effort or difficulty
example: The onerous task of checking each entry manually took several days.

definition: not able to be seen through; not transparent
example: The opaque curtains blocked out all the light.

definition: to express an opinion
example: The critic opined that the film was a masterpiece.

definition: suitable or happening at a time that is suitable or convenient
example: His arrival at that opportune moment saved the situation.

definition: harsh criticism or censure
example: His actions brought opprobrium from all sides of the political spectrum.

definition: great wealth or luxuriousness
example: The hotel was known for its opulence and extravagant decor.

definition: to call into question the truth or validity of something
example: They sought to oppugn the witness's testimony by highlighting inconsistencies.

definition: ostentatiously costly and luxurious
example: They live in an opulent mansion with marble floors and crystal chandeliers.

definition: the art or practice of formal speaking in public
example: His powerful oratory moved the crowd to action.

definition: order or decree
example: The court ordained that the children should live with their mother.

definition: following or conforming to the traditional or generally accepted rules
example: He holds orthodox views on economic policy.

definition: move or swing back and forth
example: The fan oscillated to cool the entire room.

definition: characterized by vulgar or pretentious display
example: She disliked his ostentatious displays of wealth.

definition: exclude from a society or group
example: The whistleblower was ostracized by his former colleagues.

definition: looking or sounding bizarre or unfamiliar
example: He made outlandish claims about having supernatural powers.

definition: old-fashioned
example: His outmoded views on gender roles were not well-received by younger colleagues.

definition: done or shown openly; plainly apparent
example: There was no overt sign of disagreement during the meeting.

definition: an introduction to something more substantial
example: The peace talks were just an overture to more detailed negotiations.

definition: in a state of nervous excitement or anxiety
example: She was too overwrought to speak coherently after the accident.

definition: quell the anger
example: agitation

definition: pleasant to taste
example: The chef made the bitter medicine more palatable by mixing it with honey.

definition: able to be touched or felt
example: There was a palpable sense of relief when the exam was over.

definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
example: Exercise is not a panacea for all health problems.

definition: flamboyant confidence of style or manner
example: He played the role with panache and won critical acclaim.

definition: prevalent throughout an entire country or the world
example: The pandemic affected almost every country on Earth.

definition: wild and noisy disorder or confusion; uproar
example: Pandemonium broke out when the fire alarm sounded.

definition: gratify or indulge an immoral or distasteful desire or taste
example: The newspaper was accused of pandering to people's fear of crime.

definition: a public speech or published text in praise of someone or something
example: The eulogy was a moving panegyric to his lifetime of service.

definition: a typical example or pattern of something
example: The company became a paradigm of successful online retail.

definition: a seemingly absurd or contradictory statement that may nonetheless be true
example: The paradox of the situation was that by losing the battle

definition: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality
example: She was considered a paragon of virtue in the community.

definition: more important than anything else
example: Safety is paramount when working with dangerous materials.

definition: extreme and unreasonable feeling that other people do not like you or want to harm you
example: His paranoia made him suspicious of his closest friends.

definition: express the meaning of something using different words
example: Can you paraphrase the author's main argument?

definition: an outcast
example: After the scandal
sent: he became a pariah in the business community.

definition: an imitation of the style of a particular writer or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect
example: The film was a parody of classic horror movies.

definition: a sudden attack or outburst of a particular emotion or activity
example: He collapsed in a paroxysm of coughing.

definition: unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy
example: The parsimonious manager refused to replace the outdated equipment.

definition: a strong supporter of a party or cause
example: She was a partisan of environmental causes long before they became popular.

definition: a satire or lampoon
example: The political cartoon was a scathing pasquinade of the corrupt official.

definition: an artistic work consisting of a medley of pieces imitating various sources
example: The novel was a pastiche of detective fiction styles through the ages.

definition: obvious
example: It was patent to everyone that he was lying.

example: The neighborhood is becoming less homogeneous as different cultures move in.

definition: excessive pride or self-confidence
example: His hubris led him to believe he could never fail.

definition: exaggerated statements not meant to be taken literally
example: The claim that he "died of embarrassment" was mere hyperbole.

definition: a person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions
example: She was an iconoclast who challenged traditional scientific thinking.

definition: a peculiar behavioral characteristic of an individual
example: One of his idiosyncrasies was always aligning his pencils perfectly on his desk.

definition: extremely happy
example: peaceful

definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
example: The team suffered an ignominious defeat in the championship game.

definition: based on or producing illusion; deceptive
example: The apparent economic recovery proved illusory as unemployment continued to rise.

definition: about to happen
example: An announcement about the merger is imminent.

definition: unchangeable over time or unable to be changed
example: The laws of physics are immutable.

definition: treating all rivals or disputants equally
example: The judge remained impartial throughout the controversial trial.

definition: not showing or feeling emotion
example: The poker player maintained an impassive expression despite having a winning hand.

definition: not showing proper respect; rude
example: The child asked impertinent questions about the visitor's age.

definition: unable to be affected by
example: She seemed impervious to criticism.

definition: acting or done quickly and without thought or care
example: He made an impetuous decision to quit his job without having another one lined up.

definition: unable to be appeased or placated
example: She was implacable in her opposition to the proposed changes.

definition: implied though not directly expressed
example: There was an implicit agreement among the friends to avoid discussing politics.

definition: a spoken curse
example: He muttered imprecations under his breath as he tried to fix the broken pipe.

definition: failure to observe standards of honesty or modesty
example: The scandal involved financial impropriety by several executives.

definition: not having or showing foresight; spendthrift or thoughtless
example: His improvident spending left him with no savings for retirement.

definition: not showing care for the consequences of an action
example: It would be imprudent to invest all your money in a single stock.

definition: not showing due respect
example: The impudent child talked back to his teacher.

definition: dispute the truth or validity of a statement
example: The lawyer tried to impugn the witness's testimony by pointing out inconsistencies.

definition: attribute something to someone
example: The media imputed corrupt motives to the politician's actions.

definition: not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning
example: She made an inadvertent error in her calculations.

definition: lacking sense or meaning; silly
example: The movie was full of inane dialogue that added nothing to the plot.

definition: continuing without pause or interruption
example: The incessant barking of the dog kept them awake all night.

definition: just begun and so not fully formed or developed
example: The revolution was still in an inchoate stage.

definition: having or showing the ability to identify the core of an issue
example: Her incisive analysis identified the key factors behind the company's failure.

definition: a feeling that makes a person want to do something
example: She had no inclination to pursue a career in medicine.

definition: expressed in an incomprehensible or confusing way
example: His explanation was so incoherent that no one understood what he meant.

definition: not in harmony or keeping with surroundings or other aspects
example: The modern skyscraper looked incongruous among the historic buildings.

definition: not able to be corrected or reformed
example: He was an incorrigible optimist who always saw the best in every situation.

definition: unwilling or unable to believe something
example: She was incredulous when he told her he had won the lottery.

definition: necessary for someone as a duty or responsibility
example: It is incumbent upon the president to promote unity.

definition: having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned
example: She was indifferent to the praise she received for her work.

definition: originating or occurring naturally in a particular place
example: Kangaroos are indigenous to Australia.

definition: poor; needy
example: The charity provides food for indigent families in the community.

definition: feeling or showing anger because of something unjust
example: She was indignant about being overlooked for promotion.

definition: wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
example: He spent an indolent summer lounging by the pool.

definition: impossible to subdue or defeat
example: She showed indomitable courage in the face of adversity.

definition: impossible to doubt; unquestionable
example: The evidence of his guilt was indubitable.

definition: too great or extreme to be expressed in words
example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

definition: not able to be avoided or escaped
example: Death is an ineluctable fact of life.

definition: having or showing no skill
example: His inept handling of the crisis made the situation worse.

definition: a tendency to do nothing or to remain unchanged
example: Once he retired
sent: he found it hard to overcome the inertia that kept him on the couch.

definition: certain to happen; unavoidable
example: With dark clouds gathering

definition: impossible to stop or prevent
example: The inexorable advance of technology is changing every aspect of our lives.

definition: incapable of making mistakes or being wrong
example: Even the most expert doctors are not infallible.

definition: well known for some bad quality or deed
example: The area was infamous for its high crime rate.

definition: unfortunate; inappropriate
example: His infelicitous remark caused an awkward silence at the dinner table.

definition: extremely small
example: The chance of winning the lottery is infinitesimal.

definition: physical or mental weakness
example: Age brings various infirmities.

definition: a change in the pitch or tone of a person's voice
example: I could tell from the inflection in her voice that she was upset.

definition: innocent and unsuspecting
example: His ingenuous trust in others sometimes led to disappointment.

definition: bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or pleasing them
example: He tried to ingratiate himself with his new boss by complimenting her management style.

definition: tending to obstruct or harm
example: Excessive bureaucracy is inimical to innovation.

definition: gross injustice or wickedness
example: The dictator's rule was marked by iniquity and oppression.

definition: an authoritative warning or order
example: The court issued an injunction preventing the company from continuing its harmful practices.

definition: inborn; natural
example: She has an innate talent for music.

definition: not harmful or offensive
example: His comments seemed innocuous but caused unexpected offense.

definition: introducing new ideas or methods
example: The company is known for its innovative approach to problem-solving.

definition: unusually or disproportionately large
example: The project required an inordinate amount of time to complete.

definition: impossible to understand or interpret
example: His inscrutable expression gave no hint of his thoughts.

definition: proceeding in a gradual
example: subtle way with harmful effects
sent: The insidious effects of the pollution weren't noticed until years later.

definition: suggest or hint in an indirect and unpleasant way
example: She insinuated that I had not been doing my fair share of the work.

definition: lacking flavor or interest
example: The critic described the movie as an insipid attempt at comedy.

definition: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect
example: The customer was insolent to the waitstaff when his meal was delayed.

definition: showing a casual lack of concern
example: He displayed an insouciant attitude toward his approaching deadlines.

definition: unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence
example: The company's most valuable assets were intangible - its reputation and brand recognition.

definition: necessary to make a whole complete
example: Trust is an integral part of any successful relationship.

definition: able to be understood
example: The poor connection made his words barely intelligible over the phone.

definition: lacking in self-control
example: His intemperate remarks during the debate damaged his reputation.

definition: a person who takes part in a dialogue or conversation
example: The journalist proved to be a skilled interlocutor during the interview.

definition: endless or seemingly endless
example: The meeting felt interminable as it dragged into its fourth hour.

definition: destructive to both sides in a conflict
example: The company was damaged by internecine struggles between departments.

definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree
example: The intransigent position of both parties made negotiation impossible.

definition: fearless; adventurous
example: The intrepid explorer ventured into unknown territory.

definition: belonging naturally; essential
example: The intrinsic value of gold makes it a good investment during economic uncertainty.

definition: examining one's own thoughts and feelings
example: She became more introspective after her near-death experience.

definition: overwhelm with things or people to be dealt with
example: After the announcement

definition: accustom someone to something unpleasant
example: Years of working in emergency services had inured him to the sight of blood.

definition: insulting or abusive language
example: The debate degenerated into invective and personal attacks.

definition: having a particular habit or interest that is long-established
example: He's an inveterate gambler who can't resist a bet.

definition: likely to arouse resentment
example: She found herself in the invidious position of having to choose between her friends.

definition: give strength or energy to
example: The brisk walk in the cold air invigorated her.

definition: impossible to defeat or overcome
example: The team seemed invincible as they won their tenth consecutive game.

definition: never to be broken or dishonored
example: Freedom of speech is considered an inviolable right in democracies.

definition: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered
example: The irascible old man yelled at children who came near his property.

definition: irritating or annoying
example: She found her daily commute increasingly irksome.

definition: impossible to repair or make good
example: The accident caused irreparable damage to the antique vase.

definition: not able to be changed or reversed
example: Once submitted

definition: traveling from place to place
example: The itinerant worker moved wherever there were seasonal jobs available.

definition: having or showing prejudice
example: He takes a jaundiced view of any new government initiatives.

definition: naive
example: simplistic

definition: put at risk
example: The scandal jeopardized his chance of winning the election.

definition: throw or drop something from an aircraft or ship
example: They had to jettison some fuel before the emergency landing.

definition: extreme patriotism
example: especially in the form of aggressive foreign policy
sent: The newspaper was criticized for promoting jingoism during the conflict.

definition: fond of or characterized by joking; humorous
example: His jocular manner made him popular at parties.

definition: cheerful and friendly
example: The jovial host made everyone feel welcome at the party.

definition: showing good judgment
example: The manager made a judicious decision to delay the project.

definition: a huge
example: powerful

definition: a particular point in time
example: At this critical juncture
sent: we need to decide whether to continue the project.

definition: the theory or philosophy of law
example: She studied jurisprudence at Oxford University.

definition: place or deal with close together for contrasting effect
example: The documentary juxtaposes the wealth of the city with the poverty of the surrounding areas.

definition: a constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements
example: The festival was a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds.

definition: extremely difficult or complex
example: The negotiators faced a knotty problem that had no easy solution.

definition: tearful or given to weeping
example: The movie's lachrymose ending left many in the audience crying.

definition: lacking in vitality
example: force

definition: using very few words
example: His laconic reply of "maybe" left me uncertain of his intentions.

definition: a person who makes slow progress and falls behind others
example: The company was a laggard in adopting new technologies.

definition: criticize harshly
example: The critic lambasted the film for its poor acting and predictable plot.

definition: publicly criticize by using ridicule or satire
example: The sketch show lampoons political figures from all parties.

definition: lacking in vigor or vitality; slow and relaxed
example: She spent a languid afternoon reading in the hammock.

definition: lose or lack vitality; grow weak
example: The project languished after losing its main source of funding.

definition: generosity in bestowing money or gifts
example: The charity event benefited from the largesse of several wealthy donors.

definition: feeling or revealing an overt sexual interest or desire
example: He gave her a lascivious look that made her uncomfortable.

definition: existing but not yet developed or manifest
example: She had a latent talent for music that wasn't discovered until adulthood.

definition: deserving praise and commendation
example: His laudable efforts to help the community were recognized with an award.

definition: sumptuously rich
example: elaborate

definition: lack of strictness
example: severity

definition: having or showing excessive sexual desire
example: She quit her job because of her boss's lecherous behavior.

definition: conforming to the law or to rules
example: The police questioned whether his business activities were legitimate.

definition: affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic
example: The hot weather made everyone feel lethargic and unwilling to work.

definition: a lack of energy and enthusiasm
example: After lunch
sent: a lethargy seemed to settle over the office.

definition: humor or frivolity
example: especially when inappropriate
sent: The judge scolded the attorney for his levity during the serious proceedings.

definition: a person who freely indulges in sensual pleasures
example: In his youth
sent: he had been known as a libertine

definition: promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters
example: The novel was considered too licentious to be included in the school library.

definition: clear and transparent
example: Her limpid explanation made the complex subject easy to understand.

definition: treat as an object of great interest or importance
example: The returning astronauts were lionized by the media.

definition: tending to talk a great deal; garrulous
example: My loquacious seatmate on the plane told me his life story in great detail.

definition: expressed clearly; easy to understand
example: Her lucid explanation helped me understand the complex concept.

definition: so foolish or unreasonable as to be amusing
example: His claim to have read 100 books in a week was ludicrous.

definition: looking or sounding sad and dismal
example: He gave a lugubrious sigh as he contemplated the work ahead.

definition: giving off light; bright or shining
example: The luminous moon lit up the night sky.

definition: very vivid in color
example: especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or jarring effect
sent: The tabloid published lurid details of the celebrity scandal.

definition: having luster; shining
example: Her lustrous hair gleamed in the sunlight.

definition: rich and profuse in growth
example: The valley was covered with luxuriant vegetation.

definition: disturbing because concerned with or causing a fear of death
example: The haunted house was decorated with macabre images of skeletons and ghosts.

definition: generous or forgiving
example: especially toward a rival or less powerful person
sent: The champion was magnanimous in victory

definition: a wealthy and influential businessperson
example: The media magnate owned newspapers in several countries.

definition: having or showing great authority
example: The professor delivered a magisterial lecture on ancient Rome.

definition: using high-flown or bombastic language
example: His magniloquent speech impressed some but struck others as pompous.

definition: ineffective or bungling; clumsy
example: His maladroit handling of the situation only made things worse.

definition: a general feeling of discomfort or unease
example: The economic downturn created a malaise that affected consumer confidence.

definition: the mistaken use of a word in place of a similar-sounding one
example: Her malapropism
column5:
caused much amusement.,False
malcontent,a person who is dissatisfied and rebellious,The organization was challenged by a group of malcontents who opposed the new policies.,False
malediction,a curse,The defeated wizard uttered a malediction against his conqueror.,False
malefactor,a person who commits a crime or does wrong,The police were searching for the malefactor who had vandalized the park.,False
malevolent,having or showing a wish to do evil to others,The villain in the story was a malevolent sorcerer bent on revenge.,False
malfeasance,wrongdoing, especially by a public official,The mayor was investigated for malfeasance after allegations of corruption.
malign,evil in nature or effect,The drug had malign side effects that weren't discovered until years later.,False
malleable,easily influenced; pliable,Young minds are malleable and open to new ideas.,False
malodorous,smelling very unpleasant,The malodorous garbage had to be removed immediately.,False
mandate,an official order or commission to do something,The election victory gave the party a mandate to implement its policies.,False
manifest,clear or obvious to the eye or mind,The effects of the drought were manifest in the withered crops.,False
manifold,many and various,The problem has manifold causes that need to be addressed separately.,False
manipulate,control or influence cleverly or unscrupulously,The politician tried to manipulate public opinion through misleading statements.,False
marginalize,treat a person or group as insignificant or peripheral,The new policy would marginalize rural communities.,False
martial,relating to fighting or war,The country has a long martial tradition.,False
martinet,a strict disciplinarian,The new teacher was a martinet who tolerated no talking in class.,False
maudlin,self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental,After a few drinks, he became maudlin and started reminiscing about his childhood.
maunder,talk in a rambling manner,The elderly patient would maunder about events from decades ago.,False
maverick,an unorthodox or independent-minded person,He was a maverick in the industry, always trying unconventional approaches.
mawkish,sentimental in an exaggerated or false way,The film's mawkish ending was too sweet to be believable.,False
maxim,a short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct,The coach often repeated the maxim
meander,to wander aimlessly,The river meanders through the valley before reaching the sea.,False
mediate,intervene in a dispute to bring about an agreement,The diplomat tried to mediate between the warring factions.,False
mediocre,of only moderate quality; not very good,Despite good reviews, I found the movie mediocre at best.
meditation,the practice of focusing one's mind for a period of time,She found that daily meditation reduced her stress levels.,False
melancholy,a feeling of pensive sadness,The rainy weather added to her sense of melancholy.,False
mellifluous,sweet or musical; pleasant to hear,She had a mellifluous voice that was perfect for radio.,False
mendacious,not telling the truth; lying,His mendacious account of the events was soon exposed.,False
mercenary,primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics,His mercenary attitude made him unpopular with his colleagues.,False
mercurial,subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind,Her mercurial temperament made her difficult to work with.,False
meretricious,attractive in a showy or false way,The restaurant's meretricious decor couldn't compensate for its mediocre food.,False
mesmerize,capture the complete attention of someone,The dancer's performance mesmerized the audience.,False
metamorphosis,a complete change of form or character,The caterpillar undergoes a metamorphosis to become a butterfly.,False
meticulous,showing great attention to detail,She was meticulous in checking every calculation in the report.,False
milieu,a person's social environment,He thrived in the competitive milieu of Wall Street.,False
minatory,expressing or conveying a threat,The principal's minatory glare silenced the noisy classroom.,False
mindful,conscious or aware of something,She's always mindful of the impact her words can have on others.,False
minuscule,extremely small,The difference between the two products is minuscule.,False
minute,extremely small,There was a minute amount of poison, not enough to cause harm.
minutiae,the small, precise, or trivial details of something
mirage,an optical illusion caused by atmospheric conditions,The travelers saw a mirage of water in the desert.,False
mirth,amusement, especially as expressed in laughter,The comedian's jokes provoked much mirth in the audience.
misanthrope,a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society,The misanthrope lived alone in a remote cabin, avoiding all contact with people.
misconstrue,interpret wrongly,She misconstrued his silence as agreement rather than confusion.,False
miscreant,a person who behaves badly or in a way that breaks the law,The police were searching for the miscreant who had vandalized the park.,False
miser,a person who hoards wealth and spends as little as possible,Despite his millions, he lived like a miser
misogynist,a person who dislikes or is prejudiced against women,He was revealed to be a misogynist after his discriminatory hiring practices were exposed.,False
mitigate,make less severe or serious,The new measures helped mitigate the effects of the drought.,False
mnemonic,a device such as a pattern of letters that aids memory,The mnemonic Every Good Boy Deserves Fudge" helps remember musical notes.

definition: a small quantity of a particular thing
example: He showed a modicum of interest in the proposal.

definition: a small quantity of a particular thing
example: Even a modicum of exercise can improve your health.

definition: the act of changing between different states
example: The singer's voice modulation was impressive
sent: shifting easily between high and low notes.

definition: appease the anger or anxiety of someone
example: He tried to mollify the customer by offering a discount.

definition: of great importance or significance
example: They awaited the momentous decision of the Supreme Court.

definition: relating to monks or life in a monastery
example: He preferred a monastic lifestyle of simplicity and quiet.

definition: lack of variety and interest; tedious repetition
example: The monotony of the long journey made it difficult to stay awake.

definition: subject to debate or uncertainty
example: Whether this approach is better becomes a moot point if we can't afford it.

definition: at the point of death; in terminal decline
example: The moribund company was unlikely to survive another year.

definition: sullen and ill-tempered
example: He became morose after losing his job and rarely smiled.

definition: a reason for doing something
example: The police tried to establish a motive for the crime.

definition: many and of various types
example: The report outlined the multifarious causes of the economic collapse.

definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
example: She was tired of her mundane job and wanted a new challenge.

definition: characterized by great generosity
example: The munificent donation allowed the hospital to build a new wing.

definition: a countless or extremely great number
example: The night sky was filled with a myriad of stars.

definition: the lowest point
example: The company's stock reached its nadir during the financial crisis.

definition: just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential
example: The nascent technology showed promise but needed further development.

definition: wicked or criminal
example: The detective uncovered a nefarious plot to steal the crown jewels.

definition: failing to take proper care
example: The driver was found negligent in causing the accident.

definition: a newly coined word or expression
example: Social media has introduced many neologisms into everyday language.

definition: a person who is new to a subject or activity
example: As a neophyte in the financial world
sent: she had a lot to learn.

definition: the practice of favoring relatives in employment
example: His promotion was viewed as nepotism since his uncle was the CEO.

definition: irritate or annoy
example: His criticism nettled her more than she wanted to admit.

definition: a connection or series of connections
example: The investigation revealed a nexus between the company and organized crime.

definition: take small bites
example: The children nibbled on their cookies to make them last longer.

definition: appearing casually calm and relaxed
example: He was nonchalant about the upcoming exam despite its importance.

definition: so surprised and confused that one is unsure how to react
example: She was nonplussed by his unexpected marriage proposal.

definition: a medicine prepared by an unqualified person
example: The traveling salesman sold nostrums that he claimed could cure any ailment.

definition: famous for some bad quality or deed
example: The area was notorious for its high crime rate.

definition: a person new to and inexperienced in a job or situation
example: As a novice driver
sent: she was nervous on the highway.

definition: harmful or toxic to living things
example: The factory released noxious fumes into the air.

definition: of no value or importance
example: Their objections proved nugatory as the project went ahead anyway.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
example: He remained obdurate in his opposition to the new policy.

definition: render obscure or unclear
example: The politician tried to obfuscate the issue with complicated language.

definition: not aware of or concerned about what is happening
example: She was oblivious to the chaos around her as she read her book.

definition: strong public condemnation
example: The disgraced politician faced obloquy after the scandal.

definition: extremely unpleasant
example: His obnoxious behavior at the party offended many guests.

definition: not clearly expressed or easily understood
example: The professor's explanation was so obscure that few students understood it.

definition: obedient or attentive to an excessive degree
example: The obsequious waiter hovered around the table
sent: constantly asking if everything was satisfactory.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action
example: She was obstinate in her refusal to apologize.

definition: noisy and difficult to control
example: The obstreperous children made it impossible to hear the movie.

definition: slow to understand
example: He was being deliberately obtuse about the simple concept.

definition: remove a need or difficulty
example: The new system will obviate the need for manual data entry.

definition: extremely unpleasant; repulsive
example: The dictator's odious policies led to widespread human rights abuses.

definition: intrusively enthusiastic in offering help or advice
example: The officious clerk kept suggesting products I didn't want.

definition: a small group of people having control of a country or organization
example: The country had become an oligarchy controlled by a few wealthy families.

definition: giving the worrying impression that something bad is going to happen
example: The dark clouds were ominous

definition: having unlimited power; able to do anything
example: In many religions

definition: knowing everything
example: The novelist created an omniscient narrator who could see into all characters' thoughts.

definition: involving a great deal of effort or difficulty
example: The onerous task of checking each entry manually took several days.

definition: not able to be seen through; not transparent
example: The opaque curtains blocked out all the light.

definition: to express an opinion
example: The critic opined that the film was a masterpiece.

definition: suitable or happening at a time that is suitable or convenient
example: His arrival at that opportune moment saved the situation.

definition: harsh criticism or censure
example: His actions brought opprobrium from all sides of the political spectrum.

definition: great wealth or luxuriousness
example: The hotel was known for its opulence and extravagant decor.

definition: to call into question the truth or validity of something
example: They sought to oppugn the witness's testimony by highlighting inconsistencies.

definition: ostentatiously costly and luxurious
example: They live in an opulent mansion with marble floors and crystal chandeliers.

definition: the art or practice of formal speaking in public
example: His powerful oratory moved the crowd to action.

definition: order or decree
example: The court ordained that the children should live with their mother.

definition: following or conforming to the traditional or generally accepted rules
example: He holds orthodox views on economic policy.

definition: move or swing back and forth
example: The fan oscillated to cool the entire room.

definition: characterized by vulgar or pretentious display
example: She disliked his ostentatious displays of wealth.

definition: exclude from a society or group
example: The whistleblower was ostracized by his former colleagues.

definition: looking or sounding bizarre or unfamiliar
example: He made outlandish claims about having supernatural powers.

definition: old-fashioned
example: His outmoded views on gender roles were not well-received by younger colleagues.

definition: done or shown openly; plainly apparent
example: There was no overt sign of disagreement during the meeting.

definition: an introduction to something more substantial
example: The peace talks were just an overture to more detailed negotiations.

definition: in a state of nervous excitement or anxiety
example: She was too overwrought to speak coherently after the accident.

definition: quell the anger
example: agitation

definition: pleasant to taste
example: The chef made the bitter medicine more palatable by mixing it with honey.

definition: able to be touched or felt
example: There was a palpable sense of relief when the exam was over.

definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
example: Exercise is not a panacea for all health problems.

definition: flamboyant confidence of style or manner
example: He played the role with panache and won critical acclaim.

definition: prevalent throughout an entire country or the world
example: The pandemic affected almost every country on Earth.

definition: wild and noisy disorder or confusion; uproar
example: Pandemonium broke out when the fire alarm sounded.

definition: gratify or indulge an immoral or distasteful desire or taste
example: The newspaper was accused of pandering to people's fear of crime.

definition: a public speech or published text in praise of someone or something
example: The eulogy was a moving panegyric to his lifetime of service.

definition: a typical example or pattern of something
example: The company became a paradigm of successful online retail.

definition: a seemingly absurd or contradictory statement that may nonetheless be true
example: The paradox of the situation was that by losing the battle

definition: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality
example: She was considered a paragon of virtue in the community.

definition: more important than anything else
example: Safety is paramount when working with dangerous materials.

definition: extreme and unreasonable feeling that other people do not like you or want to harm you
example: His paranoia made him suspicious of his closest friends.

definition: express the meaning of something using different words
example: Can you paraphrase the author's main argument?

definition: an outcast
example: After the scandal
sent: he became a pariah in the business community.

definition: an imitation of the style of a particular writer or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect
example: The film was a parody of classic horror movies.

definition: a sudden attack or outburst of a particular emotion or activity
example: He collapsed in a paroxysm of coughing.

definition: unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy
example: The parsimonious manager refused to replace the outdated equipment.

definition: a strong supporter of a party or cause
example: She was a partisan of environmental causes long before they became popular.

definition: a satire or lampoon
example: The political cartoon was a scathing pasquinade of the corrupt official.

definition: an artistic work consisting of a medley of pieces imitating various sources
example: The novel was a pastiche of detective fiction styles through the ages.

definition: obvious
example: It was patent to everyone that he was lying.
